name: The Future Explored in Movies Multiple Choice Quiz | Movies | 10 Questions

questions.text: (1971) The future of England involves violent youth gangs dressed in bizarre matching uniforms and battling for territory.  The government appears to be socialistic, with law enforcement methods callous and punishment methods stringently enforced.
questions.explanation:
A Clockwork Orange.

	'A Clockwork Orange' is based on the novel by Anthony Burgess and the screen play by director Stanley Kubrick.  Malcolm McDowell stars as Alexander de Large, the protagonist and antagonist all rolled into one. In the film, Alexander de Large is a member of the youth gangs mentioned previously.  After committing murder, he is subjected to a rigorous corrective method that involves mental conditioning, with naturally disastrous results.

questions.text: (1982) Everything is dark and digital advertising is omnipresent in the future Los Angeles presented in this film.  While humans continue their mundane existence on Earth, some have ventured forth into space.  Much of the dirty work in space is handled by androids with limited lifespans.
questions.explanation:
Blade Runner.

	Harrison Ford stars in this Ridley Scott-directed film about a bounty hunter (played by Ford) who is hired to hunt down and terminate the lives of several androids (Replicants) who have gotten loose in the Los Angles of the future.  Story by Philip K. Dick.

questions.text: (1989) The future in the sequel to this popular film is pleasant, with self-drying clothing and hovering skateboards.  Oh yes, in this future, the Chicago Cubs finally win the World Series!
options: Close Encounters of the Third Kind
questions.explanation:
Back to the Future.

	'Back to the Future II' sees Marty McFly (Michael J. Fox) once again drawn into an adventure he doesn't choose.  This time, he views his own disturbing future, and is eventually drawn back to 1955 (as in the original film) when Biff gets a hold of a sports almanac and the keys to Marty's time machine.

questions.text: (1968) The future in this movie features human settlement on the moon, large spinning space vehicles and hyper-egotistic computers that take control of spacecraft.
questions.explanation:
2001: A Space Odyssey.

	Another film by Kubrick, this is an all-time classic visual treat.  After a strange artifact is located on the moon, exploration of the space around Jupiter, where the artifact is believed to have originated from, ensues.  All bets are off, however, when a spacecraft computer called HAL-9000 goes a little loopy.  The original story was written by Arthur Clarke.

questions.text: (2002) In this film future, people are arrested *before* they commit their crimes.
questions.explanation:
Minority Report.

	'Minority Report' is the story of a police detective (Tom Cruise) who happily goes about his business of arresting people before they commit crimes (aka 'pre-crime'), that is, until his number comes up.  Steven Spielberg directs this thriller, based on a story by Philip K. Dick.

questions.text: (1985) In this dystopia, terrorists are loose in a society rife with technocrats and paperwork, though technology has hardly advanced beyond the 1980s.
questions.explanation:
Brazil.

	Terry Gilliam directs and Jonathan Pryce stars as Sam Lowry, a technocrat who is involved in getting the wrong man arrested for a terrorist incident.  When Lowry attempts to rectify the situation, he is also accused of being a terrorist and is forced to run.  Tom Stoppard and Charles McKeown co-wrote the screenplay with Gilliam in this magnificent vision of a frightening future.

questions.text: (1997) Mankind is locked in an epic struggle against the 'bugs', with the future of our galaxy at stake.  In this future, the greatest achievement is to join the military where you can fight and die in a seemingly endless war.
questions.explanation:
Starship Troopers.

	'Starship Troopers' is a peek into a fascistic future created by Robert Heinlein in his original novel, and brought to the screen by director Paul Verhoeven.  Violently satiristic of modern society, the film is meant to poke fun at jingoistic politics, and only suffers a bit because of its candy-coated cast.

questions.text: (2002) Human beings have reached deep into space for the purposes of exploration.  Despite a huge advancement in technology, our desires, personal practices and failings remain the same.  Apparently, pscyhologists have not made many great advancements.
questions.explanation:
Solaris.

	The 2002 version of 'Solaris' features George Clooney as a psychologist who is sent deep into space to investigate a situation on a research ship where the crew are experiencing strange mental phenomena. It is based on the original Russian film from 1972.  While the 2002 version is directed by Steven Soderbergh, Andrei Tarkovsky directs the original (based on a novel by Stanislaw Lem).

questions.text: (1987) Crime has increased to extreme levels in this future, and law enforcement is struggling to keep up.  To challenge the rampant criminal element in the city of Detroit, mechanization of law enforcement is brought into play.
questions.explanation:
RoboCop.

	'RoboCop' is another classic futuristic sci-fi film directed by Paul Verhoeven.  In this film, officer Alex Murphy (Peter Weller) is nearly killed by a street gang, but is revived and turned into a cyborg by experts affiliated with the city government.  His quest then becomes to arrest the assailant responsible for previously attacking him.

questions.text: (2001) In the bland future predicted in this film, robots called 'mechas' have advanced to the point where they can service human beings, even to the point of soothing them emotionally.
questions.explanation:
Artificial Intelligence: AI.

	Haley Joel Osment stars as David, an android boy who has joined a family in replacement of a comatose son.  When the human boy he has replaced is revived, David becomes expendible and his survival becomes a big issue.  Steven Spielberg directed this film with a fascinating premise that originally was to be directed by Stanley Kubrick. Thank you for playing, I hope you enjoyed this quiz.
